title: 107_hr2706
content: The Act titled "Medicare Telehealth Validation Act of 2001" expands and improves telehealth services. The Medicare Telehealth Validation Act of 2001 expands access to telehealth services to all areas, including entities participating in approved federal telemedicine demonstration projects. The Medicare Telehealth Validation Act of 2001 expands access to telehealth services by adding new types of originating sites, including skilled nursing facilities, assisted living facilities, board and care facilities, schools, county mental health clinics, and individual residences. The Medicare Telehealth Validation Act of 2001 aims to facilitate the provision of telehealth services across state lines by encouraging multistate practitioner licensure. The act defines telehealth services and involves consultation with various stakeholders. The terms "physician" and "practitioner" are defined in relation to subparagraphs (D) and (E) respectively. The "medicare program" refers to the health insurance program administered by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Grant program established for telehealth network development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to eligible recipients to expand access to healthcare services in rural, frontier, and medically underserved areas through telehealth. Eligible entities must submit an application with required information to receive the grant. The Secretary may require information for grant applications, including anticipated need, activities description, project continuation plan, meeting healthcare needs of rural populations, and community involvement in network development. The application for grants must show the long-term viability of the project, commitment from healthcare providers, and integration of telehealth to avoid redundancy and achieve economies of scale. Eligible entities include hospitals or healthcare providers in a network with specific requirements. Entities eligible for grants must demonstrate network use for education or economic development as required by the Secretary. Eligible organizations include community or migrant health centers, local health departments, nonprofit hospitals, private practice health professionals, publicly funded health or social services agencies, skilled nursing facilities, and publicly funded mental health facilities. Entities eligible for grants include public schools, libraries, universities, colleges, local government entities, and local health or nonhealth-related businesses. For-profit entities can be included as long as the grant recipient is a not-for-profit entity. The Secretary will prioritize financial assistance based on certain considerations, such as the applicant being a healthcare provider. The applicant for grants must be a healthcare provider in a medically underserved area, demonstrate broad geographic coverage, propose telehealth systems, and use funds for various health care applications. The applicant for grants must demonstrate long-term viability of projects through cost participation, financial support, and community backing. They must also provide a detailed plan for coordinating system use by eligible entities to prioritize health care services over non-clinical uses. The Secretary will establish the maximum amount of grant award for each fiscal year. The Secretary will publish grant terms and maximum amounts in the Federal Register or "HRSA Preview." Recipients can use grant funds for telehealth equipment and facility improvements, including computer hardware, software, and technical assistance for programming. The curr_chunk discusses the development and use of programming equipment, acquisition of instructional programming, demonstration projects for telehealth training, telenursing services, promoting patient adherence to national guidelines for chronic diseases, and covering transmission costs and specialist compensation. The curr_chunk outlines the permissible uses of funds for telehealth projects, including specialist compensation, collaboration facilitation, electronic patient record archival, and data analysis for cost-effectiveness. Prohibited uses include acquiring real property, excessive equipment purchases, and off-site transmission equipment installation. The curr_chunk details the restrictions on fund usage for telehealth projects, including limitations on off-site transmission equipment installation, construction expenses, and indirect costs exceeding 20% of the grant. The administration section emphasizes avoiding duplication of established telehealth networks and coordinating with other agencies. State agencies and not-for-profit organizations collaborate to fund meritorious proposals through grant programs. The Secretary will conduct outreach activities to inform potential end users in rural and medically underserved areas about the program. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for subsequent years. The Secretary will promptly implement the grant program. SEC. 4. JOINT WORKING GROUP ON TELEMEDICINE. The Joint Working Group on Telemedicine ensures representation of rural and medically underserved areas. Its mission includes identifying and coordinating Federal telehealth projects, analyzing the expansion of telehealth systems, and assessing their efficacy and cost-effectiveness. The Joint Working Group on Telemedicine will submit annual reports to Congress on the status of their mission and the telehealth field, including analysis of telehealth quality and recommendations for increasing access to health services in rural areas. The reports will also cover Federal activities related to telehealth. The Joint Working Group on Telemedicine will provide annual reports to Congress on telehealth progress, including Federal activities and recommendations for a coordinated strategy to improve healthcare access through telehealth. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the group to carry out their mission.
